reference_steps: Raw materials were weighed according to stoichiometric ratio and ball-milled with zirconia balls in nylon jars for 12 hours.
Additional 2 wt% PbO was introduced for compensating volatilization during sintering process.
After drying at 120°C, powders were calcined at 900°C for 4 hours and re-milled for another 6 hours.
Dried powders were mixed with polyvinyl alcohol binder and sieved through screen mesh.
Particles were pressed into pellets with diameter of 12 mm and thickness around 1.2 mm under uniaxial pressure of 15 MPa.
Green pellets were fired at 500°C for 2 hours for binder burn-out.
Specimens were sintered at 1190-1250°C for 1 hour.
Cooling process was controlled at 3°C/min till 600°C to prevent ceramics from cracking.
Natural cooling without quenching was performed below 600°C.
Sintered pellets were coated with silver paste on both surfaces and dried at 120°C for 30 minutes.
Samples were polarized in silicon oil at 150°C with DC electric field up to 4 kV/mm for 30 minutes.
test_steps: Raw materials weighed according to stoichiometric ratio with additional 2 wt% PbO
Ball-milled with zirconia balls in nylon jars for 12 h
Dried at 120 °C
Calcined at 900 °C for 4 h
Re-milled for another 6 h
Mixed with polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) binder and sieved through a screen mesh
Pressed into pellets (diameter 12 mm, thickness ~1.2 mm) under uniaxial pressure of 15 MPa
Fired at 500 °C for 2 h for binder burn-out
Sintered at 1190–1250 °C for 1 h
Cooled at 3 °C/min until 600 °C followed by natural cooling below 600 °C

reference_steps: Raw chemicals were weighed according to stoichiometric ratio and ball-milled for 12 hours with ethyl alcohol as medium.
Mixture was dried and calcined at 1250°C for 2 hours with heating rate of 5°C/min.
Calcined powder was ball-milled again in ethanol for 12 hours and dried at 90°C for 3 hours.
Mixture was pressed into pellets with diameter of 8 mm using 5 wt% PVA as binder.
Pellets were heated at 500°C for 5 hours to volatilize the PVA.
Pellets were sintered at 1450°C for 4 hours in air.
All samples were aged at room temperature for one week before testing.
Samples were coated with Ag electrodes on both sides and heated at 700°C for 30 minutes.
Samples were poled in silicone oil bath at 100°C and cooled to 0°C under DC field of 3 kV/mm.

reference_steps: All raw materials were dried in oven at approximately 120°C for 5 hours.
Weighed raw materials were mixed by ball milling for 12 hours with ethanol as medium.
Raw materials slurry was dried in oven.
Dried raw materials were calcined at 850°C for 2 hours to obtain object composition.
Calcined powder was secondly ball milled for another 12 hours to reduce particle size.
Calcined powder was dried in oven and granulated by passing through 80 mesh sieve.
5 wt% PVA aqueous solution was added as binder (approximately 10 wt% of powder mass).
Disk shape green bodies were pressed under uniaxial pressing.
Green bodies were heated to 800°C for 2 hours to remove binder.
Green bodies were sintered at 1140-1180°C for 2 hours.
As-sintered ceramic disks were polished and heated to 1100°C for 1 hour then removed directly from furnace for rapid cooling.
Silver electrodes were prepared on both surfaces of disks.
Ceramic samples were poled under electrical field of 4-7 MV/m for 5 minutes at room temperature.

reference_steps: Raw materials were precisely weighed according to stoichiometric ratios.
Materials were ball milled for 8 hours using ethanol as dispersion medium.
Mixed raw materials were dried and calcined at 850°C for 4 hours.
Calcined powder was ground again under same condition.
Obtained powder was dried, ground, and compressed into disk with diameter of 8 mm under pressure of 250 MPa.
Ceramics were sintered at 1100°C for 4 hours.
For electrical property testing, both sides were polished and coated with silver or platinum electrodes.
Samples were immersed in silicone oil at 180°C and electric field of 150-200 kV/cm was applied for 30 minutes for polarization.
test_steps: Raw materials weighed according to stoichiometric ratios

reference_steps: KICET-PZT8 piezoelectric powder, paraffin wax, ethylene-vinyl-acetate, and polystyrene were uniformly mixed using heated double planetary mixer.
Mixture was heated and extruded using twin-screw extruder to prepare piezoelectric feedstock.
Preform of 1-3 type composite was fabricated using ceramic injection molding machine with prepared feedstock.
PZT composite preform was sintered at 1250°C for 2 hours.
Polymer (EPOTEK 301) was poured into sintered preform.
Polymer-poured specimens were cured at 80°C for 12 hours.
Final cured specimens were machined into shapes optimized by simulation.
Room-temperature-curing silver electrodes were applied to machined specimens.
Polarization was performed by applying electric field of 2.5 kV/mm for 20 minutes in silicone oil bath at 120°C.
test_steps: Preparation of CIM feedstock composed of KICET-PZT8 piezoelectric powder, paraffin wax, and ethylene-vinyl-acetate (EVA).
Fabrication of 1–3 type composite preform using ceramic injection molding (CIM) machine (NEX-500, NISSEI Japan).
Sintering the PZT composite preform at 1250 °C for 2 hours.
Pouring polymer (EPOTEK 301) into the sintered preform.
Curing polymer-poured specimens at 80 °C for 12 hours.
Machining final cured specimens into shapes optimized by simulation.
Applying room-temperature-curing silver electrodes to machined specimens.
Polarization by applying an electric field of 2.5 kV/mm for 20 minutes in a silicone oil bath at 120 °C.

reference_steps: Raw materials were weighed according to stoichiometric ratio and mixed by ball-milling with ZrO2 balls in ethanol for 12 hours.
Dried mixtures were calcined at 850°C for 2 hours.
Additional 24-hour ball-milling was performed under same conditions.
Synthesized powders were ground and granulated with PVA binder.
Powders were pressed into discs measuring 12 mm diameter and 1 mm thickness under pressure of 150 MPa.
PVA was removed by heating at 650°C.
Green samples were sintered in muffle furnace at 1150°C for 3 hours (CBN) or 1100-1140°C for 3 hours (Tm-substituted CBN).
For textured ceramics: powders were placed in graphite die and heated to 990°C for 3 minutes under 60 MPa load using SPS.
Block was deformed in larger graphite die at 1130°C for 5 minutes under 40 MPa load.
Samples were annealed in muffle furnace at 1000°C for 4 hours in air.
Test surfaces were plated with heat-resistant electrodes and sintered at 570°C for 30 minutes (silver) or 950°C for 30 minutes (platinum).
Samples were poled under DC electric field of 12-15 kV/mm at 180°C for 15 minutes.
test_steps: Raw materials weighed according to stoichiometric ratio

Textured ceramics prepared via two-step spark plasma sintering (SPS): heated to 990 °C for 3 minutes at 100 °C/min under 60 MPa, followed by deformation at 1130 °C for 5 minutes under 40 MPa
Annealed at 1000 °C for 4 hours in air to remove infiltrated carbon

reference_steps: For SnS2: 4 mmol thioacetamide and 2 mmol SnCl4·5H2O were dissolved in 80 mL absolute ethanol by stirring for 30 minutes.
Mixture solution was transferred to Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 160°C for 12 hours.
After naturally cooling to room temperature, SnS2 was obtained through washing, centrifugation, and drying at 60°C.
For CdS: 20 mmol Cd(NO3)2·4H2O were combined with 60 mL ethylenediamine and stirred until transparent solution formed.
60 mmol thiourea was added to solution and magnetically stirred for 30 minutes.
Mixture solution was added to Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 160°C for 12 hours.
CdS was obtained through washing, centrifugation, and drying at 60°C.
For CdS@SnS2 composites: x mmol CdS precursor was dispersed in 80 mL absolute ethanol using ultrasonic agitation for 15 minutes.
Mixture of 2 mmol SnCl4·5H2O and 4 mmol thioacetamide was added to suspension and stirred at room temperature for 30 minutes.
Mixture solution was added to Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 160°C for 12 hours.
After naturally cooling to room temperature, samples were obtained through washing, centrifugation, and drying at 60°C.
test_steps: Dissolving 4 mmol thioacetamide (TAA) and 2 mmol SnCl4·5H2O in 80 mL absolute ethanol, stirred for 30 min.
Transferring mixture to Teflon-lined autoclave, heating at 160°C for 12 h.
Cooling, washing, centrifugation, drying at 60°C to obtain SnS2.
Combining 20 mmol Cd(NO3)2·4H2O with 60 mL ethylenediamine, stirred until transparent.
Adding 60 mmol thiourea, stirred for 30 min.
Transferring to autoclave, heating at 160°C for 12 h.
Cooling, washing, centrifugation, drying at 60°C to obtain CdS.
Dispersing x mmol CdS in 80 mL ethanol with ultrasonic agitation for 15 min (x=2,4,6,8).
Adding 2 mmol SnCl4·5H2O and 4 mmol TAA to suspension, stirred 30 min.
Heating in autoclave at 160°C for 12 h.
Cooling, washing, centrifugation, drying to obtain CS-x/2.
Mixing 0.5 g CdS and 0.5 g SnS2 with 50 mL deionized water.
Sonicating for 2 h, filtering and drying to obtain RCS.

reference_steps: PZT ceramic discs (20 mm diameter, 2 mm thickness) were coated with silver using screen printing with silver paste.
Silver-coated discs were fired at approximately 800°C in air, resulting in 25 μm silver coating thickness.
Nickel wear plates (2 mm thick) were ground to achieve planarity of approximately 10 μm and roughness of about 1 μm.
Ni wear plate was coated with silver using DC sputtering process to thickness of about 6 μm.
Coated surface was heated in flowing hydrogen gas at 700°C for 2 hours to facilitate silver diffusion into nickel.
Additional silver coating of about 3 μm thickness was applied, bringing overall Ag coating to approximately 9 μm.
For diffusion bonding: components were placed in stainless-steel vessel and evacuated to less than 10^-3 Pa.
Vessel was heated to bonding temperature (275°C or 400°C) using split furnace.
Uniaxial pressure of 20 MPa was applied for 1 hour duration.
Vessel was allowed to cool to room temperature while maintaining pressure.
For PZT discs bonded at 400°C: repoling was performed by immersing in silicone oil at 150°C and applying 15 kV DC for 15 minutes.
Bonded assemblies were subjected to thermal cycles between 250°C and room temperature for stability testing.
test_steps: Commercial PZT ceramic discs (grade SP-6) were sourced with 20 mm diameter and 2 ± 0.04 mm thickness
Both sides of PZT discs coated with silver paste via screen printing (free of glass frit) and fired at ~800°C in air to achieve ~25 μm silver coating
Bond quality between silver electrodes and PZT assessed using ultrasonic C-scan imaging
Nickel wear plates (2 mm thick) machined from Ni-200 rods and surface ground to ~10 μm planarity and ~1 μm roughness
Ni wear plates coated with ~6 μm silver via DC sputtering followed by heating in flowing hydrogen at 700°C for 2 h
Additional ~3 μm silver coating applied on Ni wear plates, total Ag thickness ~9 μm
Bonding performed under high vacuum (<10^-2 Pa) at 275°C or 400°C with 20 MPa pressure for 1 h
Thermal cycling between 250°C and room temperature (3°C/h heating rate, 2 h hold at 250°C)
Repolarization of PZT discs at 150°C using 15 kV DC potential for 15 min in silicone oil

reference_steps: Starting materials Eu2O3, GeO2, Dy2O3, La2O3 and Ho2O3 were combined in stoichiometric ratios with each dopant at 5 mol%.
Samples were first heated at 800°C for 2 hours in pure alumina crucibles under open atmosphere.
Materials were then heated to 1150°C for 10 hours followed by slow cooling.
Resulting materials were ground into powder for further characterization.
Ceramic discs were formed from obtained powder materials with 1 mm thickness and 10 mm diameter.
Ceramic discs were compacted using uniaxial pressing under 250 MPa pressure with 2 wt% of 5 wt% PVA aqueous solution as binder.
Samples were heated at 600°C for 30 minutes to eliminate organic additives.
Sintering was conducted at 1400°C for 4 hours.
Silver paste was applied to disc surfaces and fired at 650°C for 1 hour to form surface electrodes.
Electric field of 9-18 kV/mm was applied in silicon oil bath at 120°C for 30 minutes followed by 24-hour aging.

Performing TG/DTA analysis up to 1300 °C to study decomposition and oxidation processes

Sintering at 1150 °C for 10 h in alumina crucibles under open atmosphere

Applying electric field (9–18 kV/mm) in silicon oil bath (120 °C, 30 min) followed by 24-h aging

reference_steps: Raw materials BaCO3, TiO2, ZrO2, SnO2, and HfO2 were weighed according to purity and stoichiometric ratio of BaTi(1-x)(Zr1/3Sn1/3Hf1/3)xO3.
Weighed ingredients were added into alcohol and ball milled for 18 hours, then dried in oven.
Materials were calcined in muffle furnace at 1100°C for 4 hours.
Calcined materials were ball milled for 24 hours and dried again.
10 wt% polyvinyl alcohol was added to powder with uniform mixing.
Mixture was pressed into disc with diameter of 10 mm and thickness of 1 mm.
Target products were obtained by debinding process at 650°C in muffle furnace.
Final sintering process was conducted at 1350°C for 2 hours.
For piezocatalytic testing, sintered ceramics were finely ground and sieved through 100-mesh sieve.
50 mg ceramic powder was added to 50 mL dye solution and sonicated at 40 kHz, 450 W at 27-31°C for degradation testing.

reference_steps: Raw powders of (Bi0.5Na0.5)TiO3, BaCO3, TiO2, and MnO2 were weighed according to chemical formula for 0.85BNT-0.15BT + x wt%MnO2.
Materials were ball-milled with zirconia balls and ethanol at 250 rpm for 16 hours.
After drying at 80°C, mixture was added with 5 wt% polyvinyl butyral binder and passed through 250 µm mesh.
Mixed powder of about 0.5 g and SrTiO3 seed crystal was pressed into disc compact at 200 MPa.
SrTiO3 seed crystal was located at center of compact with size about 3 mm×3 mm×0.5 mm.
Compacts were heated at 700°C for 2 hours in air to remove binder.
Final sintering was conducted at 1200°C for 24 hours in air with heating and cooling rates of 150°C/h.
Compacts were placed on Pt sheet on alumina plate with alumina crucible lid covering during sintering.
Grown single crystals were removed from sintered compacts by cutting and polishing.
Ag paste was applied to {110}c faces and heated to 550°C to form electrodes.

Heating compacts at 700°C for 2 hours in air to remove binder.
Sintering at 1200°C for 24 hours in air with heating/cooling rates of 150°C/h.

reference_steps: Ta2O5, CH3COOLi·2H2O, and C4H6O6 were separately dissolved in ethanol with C4H6O6 vs. cations ratio of 2:3.
The solution was mixed with commercial LCO powders and vigorously stirred.
The mixed solution was evaporated and stirred at 80°C until a sol was formed.
The sol was aged at 120°C for 10 hours to obtain a gel.
After cooling, the gel was ground into a uniform powder.
The powder was annealed at 500°C for 12 hours and then cooled to room temperature.
For pure LTO samples, powders were compacted into disk by uniaxial pressing using polyvinyl butyral binder.
The disk was sintered in air at 500°C for 3 hours.
test_steps: Dissolve Ta2O5, CH3COOLi·2H2O, and C4H6O6 in ethanol.
Mix the solutions and evaporate while stirring at 80°C to form a sol.
Age the sol at 120°C for 10 hours to obtain a gel.
Anneal the gel at 500°C for 12 hours and cool to room temperature.

reference_steps: Raw materials BaCO3, CaCO3, TiO2, and ZrO2 were accurately weighed according to stoichiometric ratio.
Weighed powder and moderate ethanol were mixed and ball-milled for 12 hours.
Mixture was placed into an oven and dried at 120°C.
After powder was completely dried, it was calcined at 1250°C for 5 hours.
Calcined powder was ball-milled again for 12 hours.
Ball-milled powder was pressed into desired size and shape by cold isostatic press machine at 30 MPa for 15 minutes.
Sample was sintered at 1400-1500°C for 4 hours to obtain dense ceramic plate.
For electrical property measurement, ceramic sample was sanded and polished to 0.6 mm thickness.
Ceramic plate was coated with silver paste on both sides and calcined at 600°C for 30 minutes.
Ceramic plate was polarized by DC bias of 2-3 kV/mm for 30 minutes at room temperature.
test_steps: Raw materials (BaCO3, CaCO3, TiO2, ZrO2) were weighed according to stoichiometric ratios.
Weighed powder and ethanol were mixed and ball-milled for 12 hours.
Mixture was dried at 120 °C in an oven.
Dried powder was calcined at 1250 °C for 5 hours.
Calcined powder was ball-milled again for 12 hours.
Ball-milled powder was pressed into desired shapes using a cold isostatic press at 30 MPa for 15 minutes.
Pressed samples were sintered at 1400–1500 °C for 4 hours to obtain dense ceramic plates.

reference_steps: MgO, Sc2O3 and Nb2O5 were used to synthesize precursors MgNb2O6 at 1000°C and ScNbO4 at 1150°C.
MgNb2O6, ScNbO4, TiO2 and PbO powders were weighed according to stoichiometric proportion with 2 mol% extra PbO added.
Alcohol and oxide powders were mixed in 1:1 ratio by wet-milling for 24 hours.
Combined powder was calcined at 800-850°C for 2 hours.
Calcined mixture was mixed again for 12 hours.
Powder was conglutinated with polyvinyl alcohol solution and pressed into tablets under 8 MPa.
PVA was burned off at 550°C for 2 hours.
Ceramic tablets were covered by powders with same composition and sintered at 1200-1280°C for 4 hours.
Polished samples were coated with silver electrodes on both sides.
Samples were poled at 130°C for 15 minutes under 30 kV/cm electric field.

Polishing samples into cylindrical disks (11.40–11.54 mm diameter, 0.74–0.90 mm thickness) and coating with silver electrodes

family.reference: Barium Calcium Zirconate Titanate or BCZT

test_steps: Raw precursors were added to an Erlenmeyer flask and reacted with ethanol for 3 hours to obtain polymer solutions.
Solutions were dried at 120 °C for 10 hours in an oven.
Dried powders were calcined at 900 °C for 2 hours in a muffle furnace.
Precursor powders were mixed with 2 wt% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) at a weight ratio of 1:120 and pressed into disks (20 mm diameter) under 20 MPa pressure with a retention time of 150 seconds.
Disks were sintered at 1300 °C for 4 hours in air at a heating rate of 5 °C/min.
PIMNT samples were sliced into 5×5×0.5 mm³ wafers
Silver electrodes were painted onto sample surfaces
Electrodes were fired at 750 °C for 30 minutes to form electrodes
Samples were poled with an electric field of 10 kV/cm at 140 °C for 15 minutes in silicone oil
Samples were slowly cooled to room temperature while the electric field was halved
Dissolve Bi(NO3)3 and Fe(NO3)3·9H2O in deionized water with gradual addition of HNO3 under stirring.
Mix bismuth and iron nitrate solutions, then add triammonium citrate as complexing agent.
Stir the gel precursor at 90°C until water evaporates completely, forming a gel.
Calcine the gel at 550°C for 2 hours to obtain pure BiFeO3 (BFO) powder.
Mix CdCl2 solution with sodium citrate solution, then add ammonia and thiourea sequentially.
React CdS precursor mixture in a water bath at 60°C for 2.5 hours to form CdS nanosheets.
Centrifuge CdS precipitate, rinse with deionized water and ethanol, then dry at 60°C.
Disperse BFO in sodium citrate solution, add CdCl2 (volume adjusted for 10/20/30% CdS), and stir for 3 hours.
Add ammonia and thiourea to the BFO/CdS mixture, then react at 60°C for 2.5 hours.
Collect BFO/CdS composite precipitate, rinse, and dry at 60°C for different CdS ratios.
Preparation of dipeptide solution in methanol (1 mg/mL)
Deposition of 10 μL solution onto a silicon substrate
Solvent removal via spontaneous evaporation, forced drying with warm air, or spin-coating at 3000 rpm
Saturation of the film with methanol vapor (P/P0=1) in a sealed Petri dish for 10 minutes to 24 hours at room temperature
Post-saturation drying with warm air at 45°C

reference_steps: Raw materials were mixed with alcohol and ball milled for 24 hours.
Calcined powder was obtained by heating at 1300°C for 3 hours.
BCZT powders were produced by a second stage of ball milling for varying time periods (1-12 hours).
BCZT ceramic slurry was prepared by mixing ceramic powder with light-sensitive oligomers, diluent, photo-initiator and dispersant using vacuum mixer for 300 s at 2500 rpm.
Ceramic slurry was poured into VPP printer to produce ceramic green body with 30 μm layer thickness.
Debinding of ceramic green body was completed in tube furnace at 425°C for 4 hours with temperature ramp rates of 0.1-0.3°C/min in argon atmosphere.
Sample was kept at 550°C for 2 hours to remove residual carbon during sintering process.
BCZT ceramic scaffold was obtained by heating at 3°C/min to sintering temperature (1380-1440°C) and furnace cooling after holding for 3 hours.
Sintered BCZT ceramics were polarized at 15 kV for 1 hour using corona poling technique.
ITO film was glued to both sides of BCZT scaffold with silver glue and cured for 12 hours at room temperature.
test_steps: Raw materials mixed with alcohol and ball milled for 24 hours

Slurry poured into VPP printer (layer thickness 30 µm) to produce ceramic green body

Sintering at 3 °C/min to 1380-1440 °C, held for 3 hours, followed by furnace cooling
Corona poling at 15 kV for 1 hour
Electrodes applied via silver glue and ITO-covered PET film, cured at room temperature for 12 hours

reference_steps: High purity chemical powders were weighed stoichiometrically and ball milled for 24 hours at 300 rpm with alumina balls using acetone as mixing media.
Mixed powders were dried in an oven, followed by calcination at 900°C for 3 hours.
Disc-shaped pellets were prepared using ~13 mm diameter under uniaxial pressure of 200 MPa.
Sintering was carried out at 1150-1200°C for 2-4 hours.
For XRD measurements, sintered pellets were grounded and annealed at 500°C for 1 hour to remove any strain.
For electrical property measurement, samples were thinned to ~1 mm and electroded on both sides using silver paste.
Samples were annealed at 500°C for 1 hour after electrode application.
Electrical poling was done by applying DC field of 4-5 kV/mm for 15-30 min in silicone oil bath.
test_steps: Ball milled stoichiometric powders for 24 hours at 300 rpm with alumina balls using acetone
Dried the mixed powders in an oven
Calcined at 900°C for 3 hours

reference_steps: Raw materials were weighed according to stoichiometric ratio of (1-x)(0.7BiFeO3-0.3BaTiO3)-x(Bi0.5Na0.5)TiO3-5 mol% Bi2O3 with x = 0.000, 0.001, 0.002, 0.003.

method.test: spin coating followed by thermal annealing

reference_steps: LNO precursor prepared by dissolving equimolar La(NO3)3 and Ni(NO3)2 in glacial acetic acid with ethylene glycol, stirred for 1 hr.
TiO precursor prepared by dissolving Ti-n-butoxide in glacial acetic acid with ethylene glycol, stirred for 1 hr.
PZT precursor prepared by dissolving Pb(CH3COO)2 in glacial acetic acid, adding Zr(OC4H9)4 and Ti(OC4H9)4 stoichiometrically with distilled water and ethylene glycol.
10 wt% polyvinyl pyrrolidone added to PZT precursor and stirred for 1 hr, then filtered.
Buffer layers deposited by spin coating at 4000 rpm for 30 s on Pt/Ti/SiO2/Si substrate.
Buffer layers annealed at 650°C for 30 mins.
PZT film deposited by spin coating at 4000 rpm for 30 s.
Two-step annealing process: 400°C for 2 mins, then 650°C for 2 mins.
Process repeated for 12 cycles to achieve ~1000 nm thickness.
Final annealing at 650°C for 30 mins in open-air atmosphere.
Pt top electrode deposited by DC sputtering for electrical measurements.
test_steps: Prepare 0.1 M LNO precursor by dissolving equimolar La(NO3)3 and Ni(NO3)2 in glacial acetic acid, add 0.01 M ethylene glycol, stir for 1 hr
Prepare 0.3 M TiO2 precursor by dissolving Ti(OBu)4 in glacial acetic acid, add 0.01 M ethylene glycol, stir for 1 hr
Prepare PZT precursor by dissolving Pb(CH3COO)2 in glacial acetic acid, add stoichiometric Zr(OBu)4 and Ti(OBu)4, stir, then add distilled water and ethylene glycol, stir for 30 mins
Add 10 wt% polyvinylpyrrolidone to PZT solution, stir for 1 hr, filter using Whatman paper
Deposit buffer layers (TiO, LNO, LNO/TiO) via spin coating at 4000 rpm for 30 s
Anneal buffer layers at 650°C for 30 mins
Deposit PZT film via spin coating at 4000 rpm for 30 s
Perform two-step annealing for PZT: 400°C for 2 mins followed by 650°C for 2 mins
Repeat PZT deposition-annealing cycles 12 times to achieve ~1000 nm thickness
Final annealing of films at 650°C for 30 mins in open-air furnace

reference_steps: 1.0 mol% Mn-doped 0.28Pb(In1/2Nb1/2)O3-0.42Pb(Mg1/3Nb2/3)O3-0.30PbTiO3 single crystal grown along [001] by modified Bridgman method.
Single crystal cut into 6 × 6 × 0.38 mm³ unit sheets from same horizontal cross-section.
Unit sheets annealed at 600°C for 4 hours and cleaned.
Ultrathin conductive gold layers with 100 nm thickness deposited by sputtering method.
0.5 mm wide insulating margins left on alternating surfaces during electrode plating.
Direct current polarization along [001] direction at 135°C, 1 kV/mm for 10 minutes using CS2674 AX voltage tester in thermostatic oil bath.
15 layers of unit sheets bonded using E-44(6101) epoxy in electrical parallel and mechanical series configuration.
Zirconia ceramic sheets (0.5 mm thickness) affixed to top and bottom surfaces for rigidity.
Stacked samples subjected to 5 MPa pressure longitudinally using isostatic press.
Static curing for 48 hours to obtain final PSAs with dimensions 6 × 6 × 6.7 mm³.
test_steps: Grow Mn-doped 0.28Pb(In1/2Nb1/2)O3-0.42Pb(Mg1/3Nb2/3)O3-0.30PbTiO3 single crystal along [001] direction using modified Bridgman method
Cut crystal into 6 × 6 × 0.38 mm³ unit sheets from same horizontal cross-section of single crystal boule
Anneal unit sheets at 600 °C for 4 hours followed by cleaning
Deposit ultrathin conductive gold layers (100 nm thickness) on unit sheets via sputtering method
Create electrically parallel structure by leaving 0.5 mm wide insulating margins on alternating upper/lower surfaces during electrode plating
Polarize unit sheets via direct current polarization (DCP) along [001] direction at 135 °C, 1 kV/mm, and 10 minutes using CS2674 AX voltage tester in thermostatic oil bath
Bond 15 layers of unit sheets using E-44(6101) epoxy in electrical parallel and mechanical series configuration
Affix 0.5 mm thick zirconia ceramic sheets to top and bottom surfaces for rigidity
Apply 5 MPa longitudinal pressure using isostatic press and statically cure for 48 hours to obtain PSAs with dimensions 6 × 6 × 6.7 mm³
Examine internal structures of PSAs using polarized light microscope (BX51) to identify defects like air voids, cracks, and interlayer thickness inconsistencies

Final sintering at 1170°C for 3 h.
Silver paste applied to polished surface (600 μm thickness) followed by baking at 350°C for 30 min for electrical measurements.

Dried KNNS-BF-3BNZ/PDMS film cut into 3×3 cm sheets with 3 mm thickness.

reference_steps: High-purity MgO and Nb2O5 powders mixed and calcined at 1100°C for 5 hours to produce columbite precursor MgNb2O6.

Synthesized powders weighed based on PT-PZ-BLZT-xLN formula (x = 0, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7 wt%).
Secondary ball milling, drying, and sieving processes performed.
Granulated powders pressed into 12 mm thick sheets with 5% polyvinyl alcohol binder.
Sheets sintered at 600°C for 4 hours to remove binder.
Final sintering at 1230°C for 2 hours to synthesize ceramic samples.
Ceramic surfaces polished to uniform thickness of approximately 0.3 mm.

reference_steps: [001]-oriented BTO template powders synthesized from Bi2O3 and TiO2 using molten salt method with equal molar ratio of NaCl and KCl in 1:1 wt ratio.

Raw materials calcined at 700°C for 2 h.

Squares laminated under pressure of 75 MPa for 1-3 h.
Organics burned off at 600°C for 3 h.
Green bodies heated in tube furnace from 650°C to 1000°C at rate of 10°C/min for texture evolution assessment.
Green bodies sintered in oxygen atmosphere at 950°C for 0-6 h for electrical property measurements.

reference_steps: Precursors bismuth(III) nitrate pentahydrate, sodium acetate, potassium acetate, titanium(IV) butoxide, and manganese(II) acetate mixed in stoichiometric ratios for 3 mol% Mn-doped 0.8(Bi0.5Na0.5)TiO3–0.2(Bi0.5K0.5)TiO3.
Propan-2-ol and acetic acid used as solvents, with pentane-2,4-dione as polymerizing agent.
Mixture stirred at room temperature at 700 rpm.
Formamide added last for drying control.
Final 0.3 M solution allowed to polymerize for seven days before deposition.
6 layers of BNKT-20-3M deposited on commercial Pt/Ti/SiO2/Si substrate via spin-coating.
Each layer spin-coated at 500 rpm for 10 s, then at 4000 rpm for 30 s.
Heat treatments applied after each layer: evaporation at 200°C, pyrolysis at 500°C, and annealing at 750°C, each for 5 min.
After annealing, layer subjected to either fast quenching in liquid nitrogen (LNQ) or air-cooling (AC) to room temperature.
Process repeated 6 times to obtain thin-film sample approximately 220 nm thick.
Some samples further heat-treated in nitrogen atmosphere at 1 atm, 750°C for 30 min for defect passivation.
Circular Pt top electrodes with area of 0.283 mm² deposited by RF magnetron sputtering to create metal-insulator-metal structure.
test_steps: Mixing precursors in stoichiometric ratios
Stirring the mixture at room temperature at 700 rpm
Adding formamide to obtain a 0.3 M solution
Allowing the solution to polymerize for seven days
Depositing the solution via spin-coating on Pt/Ti/SiO2/Si substrates (500 rpm for 10 s, then 4000 rpm for 30 s per layer)
Applying heat treatments: evaporation at 200°C, pyrolysis at 500°C, and annealing at 750°C (each for 5 min)
Repeating spin-coating and heat treatment steps six times to form a 220 nm thick film
Optional N2 annealing at 750°C for 30 min in nitrogen atmosphere for defect passivation
Depositing circular Pt top electrodes via RF magnetron sputtering to create a MIM structure
Synthesis of 0.15PSN-0.57PMN-0.28PT matrix powder via traditional solid-state reaction method by sintering mixed raw materials at 750°C for 2 hours.
Synthesis of plate-like BaTiO3 templates with [001] orientation using topochemical transformation technique.
Slicing, stacking, and compressing embryo strips at 70°C with 10 MPa pressure for 30 minutes.
Removing organic matter by sintering at 550°C for 2 hours.
Subjecting samples to isostatic pressing at 200 MPa for 1 minute.
Final sintering in air atmosphere at 1200–1270°C for 0–11 hours.
Ball-milled raw materials (PbO, NiO, Nb2O5, ZrO2, TiO2) with zirconia balls (Φ = 1 mm, 3 mm, 5 mm, 10 mm) for 24 h and dried at 90°C.
Calcined milled PNN-PZT powders at 850°C for 4 h (heating rate: 5°C/min).
Added 0.2 wt% Li2CO3 to calcined powder as sintering aid.
Ball-milled mixture for 48 h with zirconia balls (Φ = 1 mm, 3 mm, 5 mm, 10 mm) and dried at 90°C.
Mixed PNNZT powders with ethyl alcohol, toluene, dibutyl phthalate, polyvinyl butyral, and dispersant at optimized ratio, ball-milled for 24 h with zirconia balls (Φ = 3 mm, 5 mm, 10 mm, 15 mm).
Separated PNNZT slurry from zirconia balls using mesh fabric and removed air bubbles via vacuum chamber for 15 min.
Aged slurry for 2 h at 15 rpm.
Prepared BT-template-free thick sheets via tape casting (casting speed: 1 m/min, blade gap: 85 μm; resulting thickness: 17 μm).
Mixed PNNZT powders with same organic materials, ball-milled for 24 h with zirconia balls (Φ = 3 mm, 5 mm, 10 mm, 15 mm).
Separated slurry, dispersed BT templates in ethanol via sonicator for 5 min, and added to slurry.
Removed remaining air bubbles via vacuum chamber for 15 min and aged slurry for 2 h at 15 rpm.
Prepared BT-included thin sheets via tape casting (casting speed: 1 m/min, blade gap: 8 μm; resulting thickness: 5 μm).
Alternately laminated PNNZT and PNNZT-BT sheets under 10 MPa pressure at 60°C.
Subjected laminates to warm isostatic pressing (WIP) at 25 MPa, 65°C for 20 min.
Cut laminates into 10 mm × 10 mm pieces using blade cutter.
Fired pieces at 300°C and 600°C (5 h each) to burn out organics (heating rate: 1°C/min).
Pressed fired laminates via cold isostatic press (CIP) at 200 MPa for 1 min.
Sintered specimens at 900–1025°C (25°C intervals) for 15 h under O2 atmosphere (flow rate: 1 L/min, heating rate: 1°C/min).
Applied Ag paste to sintered bodies and fired at 700°C for 10 min.
Conducted poling at 3.5 kV/mm for 20 min at room temperature in silicone oil.

Calcined powder at 900°C for 5 hours
Added 3 wt% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) binder and pressed into pellets (12-14 mm diameter) at 100 MPa
Sintered pellets at 1190°C for 2 hours in alumina crucible with MgO spacer powder
Crushed sintered pellets and annealed at 600°C for 4 hours to remove mechanical strains

Precursor powders were prepared according to stoichiometric ratios.
Components were thoroughly mixed in ethanol via ball milling for 15 h.
After drying, the mixture was placed into a covered alumina crucible and calcined at 810 °C for 5 h to produce the precursor powders.
The mixture was heated to 1200 °C and slowly cooled to 850 °C to promote single crystal growth.

test_steps: Mixing and grinding of reagents (6 mmol P25, 4-x mmol Bi2O3, x mmol La2O3, NaCl, and KCl with a molar ratio of NaCl:KCl:Bi4-xLaxTi3O12 = 50:50:1)
Calcination at 800 °C for 2 hours in a muffle furnace
Washing with deionized water to remove residual salts
Drying at 80 °C in air
Milling Bi2O3 and TiO2 powders using an agate mortar and pestle, followed by drying at 150 °C
Synthesis of Bi4Ti3O12 via solid-state reaction technique
Treating shrimp shells with 10% NaOH to remove proteins, followed by HCl treatment to remove calcium and obtain chitin
Deacetylation of chitin in 45% NaOH solution in an autoclave to yield chitosan flakes
Purification of chitosan via dissolution in 2% acetic acid, neutralization with NaOH, washing, and drying
Synthesis of graphene oxide (GO) via modified Hummers' method: mixing graphite, NaNO3, and H2SO4, followed by gradual addition of KMnO4, heating, and oxidation with H2O2
Purification of GO via centrifugation, washing with HCl and water, and drying under vacuum
Reduction of GO to reduced graphene oxide (rGO) via sonication in deionized water, addition of hydrazine hydrate, reflux heating at 100 °C for 12 h, followed by filtration, washing, and drying
Dispersion of graphene (rGO) powder in 1 vol% acetic acid via ultrasonication for 1 h to form a uniform solution
Addition of 1 wt% chitosan powder to the rGO/acetic acid solution and stirring for 6 h at room temperature
Dispersion of BiTO powder (x wt% relative to chitosan dry-base) in the chitosan/rGO solution via 30 min ultrasonication and 30 min magnetic stirring
Degassing the nanocomposite solution via ultrasonication for 15 min
Casting 12 mL of nanocomposite solution into Petri dishes and drying at 60 °C for 24 h
Poling of samples with a 6 kV/mm DC electric field for 15 min followed by 24-h aging in ambient air

reference_steps: Yb2O3, MgO and Nb2O5 were used to synthesize fine YbNbO4 and MgNb2O6 precursors.
Stoichiometric PbO, TiO2, MnO2, YbNbO4 and MgNb2O6 precursors were ball-milled in ethanol with ZrO2 media.
The mixture was calcined at 775°C for 2h followed by ball milling again.
BaTiO3 platelets prepared by topochemical microcrystal conversion were used as templates.
Organic binders and solvents were mixed with the fine matrix and ball-milled.
3 vol% BT templates were added into the slurry.
The slurry was di-aired and tape-casted by a doctor blade.
The dried tapes were cut, stacked and laminated into blocks.
After binders burning out, green samples were cold isostatic pressed at 200 MPa.
Textured ceramics were sintered between 1150 and 1200°C for 6h.
To avoid lead volatilization, samples were embedded in coarse matrix powders with same compositions during sintering process.
test_steps: Synthesized YbNbO4 and MgNb2O6 precursors by reacting Yb2O3, MgO, and Nb2O5.
Ball-milled stoichiometric PbO, TiO2, MnO2, YbNbO4, and MgNb2O6 precursors in ethanol with ZrO2 media.
Calcined the mixture at 775°C for 2 hours followed by ball milling again.
Prepared BaTiO3 (BT) platelets as templates via topochemical microcrystal conversion.
Added 3 vol% BT templates into the slurry.
Burned out binders and cold isostatic pressed green samples at 200 MPa.
Sintered textured ceramics between 1150 and 1200°C for 6 hours.
Synthesized randomly oriented Mn-doped PYN-PMN-PT ceramics without adding BT templates.

reference_steps: High purity raw materials were weighed based on stoichiometric formula for BNT-6BT ceramics.
Weighed raw materials were ball-milled for 24 h in ethanol using zirconia balls with 3 mm diameter.
Dried powders were calcined at 900°C for 4 hours.
1 mol% B3+ was added to pre-synthesized undoped and 1 mol% Mn3+ doped BNT-6BT before second milling.
Screened powders (<90 μm) were mixed with 5 wt% polyvinyl alcohol as binder.
Mixture was uniaxially pressed at 100 MPa pressure to form disc samples with 12 mm diameter.
Pre-shaped specimens were re-pressed via cold isostatic press at 150 MPa.
PVA binder was burnt out at 600°C for 4 h with 1°C/min heating rate.
Final sintering process was performed at 1150°C for 12 h in air.
test_steps: Ball-milled raw materials for 24 h in ethanol using zirconia balls (3 mm diameter).
Calcined powders at 900 °C for 4 h to analyze phase formation via XRD.
Added 1 mol% BE^3+ to pre-synthesized undoped and 1 mol% MnE^3+ doped BNT-6BT before second milling.
Mixed screened powders (<90 µm) with 5 wt% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) binder.
Uniaxially pressed at 100 MPa into 12 mm diameter discs.
Cold isostatic pressed (CIP) at 150 MPa for higher density.
Burnt out PVA binder at 600 °C for 4 h with 1 °C/min heating rate.
Sintered at 1150 °C for 12 h in air atmosphere.

reference_steps: Pure Mg substrate was mechanically ground with SiC paper up to 1000 grit and ultrasonically cleaned in ethyl alcohol.
Electrolyte was prepared with 20 g/L Na2SiO3 + 4 g/L KF + 2 g/L NaOH.
BaTiO3 powder (2 g/L or 5 g/L) was added to the electrolyte.
Mg plates were used as anode and stainless steel chamber as cathode during PEO process.
Pulse reverse power provided constant current of 2 A/dm2 for 660 s under frequency of 500 Hz and duty cycle of 15%.
Solution was cooled using water-cooling system at 30 ± 5°C during coating process.
After PEO treatment samples were rinsed in distilled water and dried in warm air.
test_steps: Mechanically grind Mg samples with SiC paper up to 1000 grit
Ultrasonically clean Mg samples in ethyl alcohol and dry in cold air
Prepare electrolyte solution with 20 g/L Na2SiO3, 4 g/L KF, and 2 g/L NaOH
Add 0 g/L (PEO), 2 g/L (PEO-BTO2), or 5 g/L (PEO-BTO5) BaTiO3 powder to the electrolyte
Perform PEO coating using Mg as anode and stainless steel chamber as cathode
Apply pulse reverse power at 2 A/dm² current density, 500 Hz frequency, 15% duty cycle for 660 s
Cool electrolyte to 30 ± 5 °C using water-cooling system during process
Rinse coated samples in distilled water and dry in warm air

reference_steps: NBT-0.6CeO2 powders (0.05-0.25 vol%) were dispersed in P(VDF-TrFE) matrix using 10 wt% DEC solvent.
Thin films were fabricated by spin-coating onto glass substrates pre-coated with aluminum electrodes.
Metal-insulator-metal structure was formed by depositing additional aluminum electrodes onto spin-coated films.
Samples were annealed at 100°C to optimize crystallinity.
For piezoelectric measurements, bulk samples were prepared by solution casting method with thickness of 30 μm.
Samples underwent DC poling at 65°C under electric field of 200 MV/m for 60 min in silicone oil bath.
Samples were slowly cooled to room temperature while maintaining electric field.
test_steps: Dispersing NBT-0.6CeO2 (0.05–0.25 vol%) in a P(VDF-TrFE) matrix using 10 wt% diethyl carbonate (DEC) solvent
Fabricating thin films (0.8–1 µm thickness) by spin-coating onto glass substrates pre-coated with aluminum electrodes
Forming a metal-insulator-metal (MIM) structure by depositing additional aluminum electrodes onto the spin-coated films
Annealing samples at 100°C to optimize crystallinity
Preparing bulk samples via solution casting method (thickness: 30 µm) for piezoelectric measurements

reference_steps: 1.74 g PVDF was dissolved in 20 ml N,N-dimethylformamide at 60°C.
10-50 wt.% BCT3 filler was added to solution after four hours of PVDF mixing in DMF.
Solution was stirred at 500 rpm on hot plate for additional four hours to achieve homogeneous distribution.
Solution was cast in cleaned petri dish and annealed in oven at 100°C for 5 hours.
Films were peeled off from glass petri dish and cut into square pieces.
Films were hot pressed at 100°C by applying 125 kg/cm2 pressure for two hours.
Silver electrodes were painted on both sides of films and heated on hot plate for one hour.
Films were poled by applying DC electric field of 100 kV/cm for 1 hour before PE measurements.
test_steps: Dissolving 1.74 g of PVDF in 20 ml of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) at 60°C
Adding 10, 20, 30, 40, and 50 wt.% of BCT3 filler after four hours of PVDF-DMF mixing
Stirring the solution at 500 rpm for an additional four hours
Casting the solution in a cleaned petri dish and annealing at 100°C for 5 h
Peeling off the films from the petri dish and cutting into square pieces
Hot pressing the films at 100°C under 125 kg/cm² pressure to reduce pores and enhance the polar beta phase

reference_steps: Raw materials were weighed according to chemical formula and adequately ball-milled for 24 h.
Powder was pre-fired in muffle furnace at 780°C for 4h at heating rate of 2°C/min.
8 wt% polyvinyl alcohol was added as binder and powder was pressed into 8 mm diameter disks at uniaxial pressure of 12 MPa.
Disks were sintered at ramp rate of 2°C/min for 3 h at 600°C to remove PVA.
Final sintering was conducted at 1000°C for 6 h to obtain ceramic wafers.
Ceramic discs with double-sided silver electrodes were polarized in silicon oil at 120°C under DC field of 5 kV/cm for 20 min.
test_steps: Raw materials weighed according to chemical formula

8 wt% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) added as binder

Sintered at 600°C for 3 hours (PVA removal) and 1000°C for 6 hours
Polarized with DC field of 5 kV/cm in silicon oil at 120°C for 20 minutes

reference_steps: Raw materials were weighed according to chemical formula and mixed using conventional solid-state reaction method.
Powders were calcined at 900°C.
Materials were sintered at 1150°C to obtain ceramic samples.
Samples were prepared for electrical measurements by applying silver electrodes.
Ceramics were poled for piezoelectric measurements.

reference_steps: Raw materials were ball milled with ethyl alcohol for 12 h at 300 r/min after weighing according to stoichiometry ratio.
Powders were dried in oven and calcined at 890°C for 6 h.
Powders were ball-milled again for 12 h.
Powder mixtures were dried, sieved, and pressed into pellets with diameter of 10 mm at 200 MPa using cold isostatic press.
Pellets were sintered in ambient air using two-step sintering technology.
Temperature was raised to 1190°C with heating rate of 10°C/min, then rapidly cooled to 1090°C and dwelled for 3-15 h.
Samples were placed in sealed crucible and covered with self-sourced powders to minimize volatilization losses.
Two sides of as-sintered samples were printed with silver paste and baked at 600°C for 30 min to form electrodes.
Samples were poled at 5 kV/cm for 30 min before piezoelectric measurements.

Sintering: heating to 1190 °C at 10 °C/min, rapid cooling to 1090 °C, dwelling for 3–15 h, followed by natural cooling

reference_steps: Raw materials were mixed and calcined at 700-875°C for 5 h.
Calcined powders were re-milled for 24 h at 250 rpm using planetary ball mill with ethanol and yttrium stabilized zirconia balls.
Calcined powders were filled into cylindric Molybdenum die covered with graphite foil.
Water (5 wt%) was added dropwise before upper punch insertion.
Force of 45 kN (400 MPa pressure) was applied for 40 min with gradual temperature increase of 5°C/min reaching 200°C.
Thermal post-treatment at 850°C for 25 min with lower pressure of 245 MPa and heating/cooling rate of 10°C/min in vacuum.
Samples were re-oxidized for 6 h at 850°C in oxygen to equilibrate point defects.
Both sides of polished pellets were coated with platinum via sputtering for electrical measurements.
DC poling at 2.5 kV/mm for 30 min at 120°C for piezoelectric measurements.
test_steps: Mixed K2CO3, Na2CO3, and Nb2O5 powders.
Calcined at 700-875 °C for 5 h.
Re-milled for 24 h at 250 rpm using a planetary ball mill with ethanol and yttrium stabilized zirconia balls.
Added 5 wt% water dropwise before cold sintering.
Cold sintering-assisted (CSA) using an SPS machine: applied 45 kN force (400 MPa) over 40 min with temperature increased at 5 °C/min to 200 °C.
Thermal post-treatment at 850 °C for 25 min under 245 MPa pressure with heating/cooling rates of 10 °C/min.
Re-oxidized for 6 h at 850 °C in oxygen atmosphere.

reference_steps: Raw powders were weighed according to proportion of corresponding components.
Weighed materials and ethanol were poured into jar and ball milled for 24 h with ZrO2 balls.
Ball-milled powders were dried and calcined at 850°C for 6 h.
Raw powders were mixed according to proportion and ball milled for 24 h with ZrO2 balls again.
Dried mixed powders were granulated into floc with 8 wt% polyvinyl alcohol as binder.
Powders were pressed into disks (1 mm thickness, 10 mm diameter) under pressure of 10 MPa.
After removing PVA, disks were buried in calcined powders and sintered at 1150°C for 3 h in air.
Heating rate was 5°C/min from RT to 1000°C, then 3°C/min beyond 1000°C.
Both sides of sintered samples were mechanically polished and brushed with silver layer.
Samples with silver electrodes were processed at 600°C for 10 min.
Poling process was carried out in silicone oil at room temperature under electric fields of 5 kV/mm for 3 min.
test_steps: Raw materials (Bi2O3, Na2CO3, K2CO3, TiO2, Ta2O5, Sb2O5, ZrO2, HfO2) are mixed with ethanol and ball milled for 24 h using ZrO2 balls.
Dried powders are calcined at 850 °C for 6 h.
Calcined powders are mixed according to composition ratios, ethanol added, and ball milled again for 24 h with ZrO2 balls.
Mixed powders are dried, granulated with 8 wt% PVA binder, and pressed into disks (10 mm diameter, 1 mm thickness) under 10 MPa pressure.
Disks are dewaxed by removing PVA and sintered at 1150 °C for 3 h in air atmosphere with heating rates of 5 °C/min (RT-1000 °C) and 3 °C/min (above 1000 °C).
Samples are processed with silver electrodes at 600 °C for 10 min.

reference_steps: High-purity oxides were weighed according to stoichiometric ratio.
Powders were ball-milled in ethanol medium with zirconia balls for 24 h.
After drying in oven, mixture was calcined at 850°C for 3 h.
Calcined powder underwent additional 12 h ball milling process in ethanol.
Powders were dried and granulated by adding 5 wt% polyvinyl alcohol.
Mixture was sieved through 80-mesh screen to obtain uniform powder particles.
Samples were crafted by uniaxially dry pressing powder mixtures with diameter of 10 mm and thickness of 1.5 mm.
Binder was removed at 550°C.
Samples underwent sintering at rate of 3°C/min, reaching temperatures between 1120-1200°C for 2 h in ambient air.
Green discs were coated with identical powder to prevent evaporation of Pb and Bi.
Ag electrodes were applied on both surfaces and fired at 600°C for 15 min.
Ceramics were poled under electric field of 4 kV/mm at 120°C for 20 min in silicon oil.

reference_steps: Water-soluble metal salts were used as starting materials for hydro-evaporation synthesis.
After evaporation at 80°C, formed precursor precipitates were additionally heated at same temperature for 30 min to dry completely.
Dry precursor precipitates were ground in agate mortar to obtain precursor powders.
Precursor powders were calcined at 650°C for 3 h in air.
Ceramic powders were pressed uniaxially at 880 MPa in 6 mm die.
Samples were sintered at various temperatures (780°C or 835°C) for 3 h in air to achieve optimal compositions and microstructures.
Ceramic samples were sliced to 200 μm thickness for electrical measurements.
Samples were electrically poled at different electric fields during 1 s soaking time at room temperature.

Uniaxial pressing at 880 MPa in a 6 mm die
Sintering at temperatures of 780°C or 835°C for 3 hours depending on composition

reference_steps: 99.9% pure chemicals were weighed and mixed in stoichiometric ratio according to formula.
Lead loss during heat treatment was balanced with 6 wt% PbO in each composition.
Sintered powder was made fine in agate mortar.
Methanol was added as dispersing agent and left for 1 h to ensure uniform mixing.
PVA (5 wt%) was added as binder with PVA-to-ceramic powder weight ratio of 1:20.
Powder was pressed into pellets using uniaxial hydraulic press at 150 MPa pressure for 3 min.
Calcination was repeated twice to achieve homogeneous and single-phase composition.
Sintering was carried out in air atmosphere at 1150°C for 4 h.
Flat surfaces of pellets were coated with gold and silver paint electrodes applied and heated at 600°C for 30 min.
Samples were poled using Belding & McLaren method by heating to 100-110°C in silicon oil and applying DC electric field of 20-30 kV/cm.
test_steps: Weighing and mixing stoichiometric ratios of PbO, BaCO3, Nb2O5, and Nd2O3 with 6 wt% excess PbO to compensate for lead loss during heat treatment.
Adding methanol as a dispersing agent and allowing it to sit for 1 hour for uniform mixing.
Adding PVA (5 wt%) as a binder with a PVA-to-ceramic powder weight ratio of 1:20.
Pressing the powder into pellets using a uniaxial hydraulic press at 150 MPa with a holding time of 3 minutes.
Sintering the pellets in an air atmosphere at 1150 °C for 4 hours.

reference_steps: Analytical reagents were mixed in stoichiometric ratios by ball milling with alcohol as solvent for 12 h.
Prepared powders were dried and calcined at 900°C.
Calcined powders were milled and dried again.
Powders were pressed into pellets using polyvinyl alcohol as binder.
Pellets were fired at 600°C to remove binder.
Samples were subsequently sintered at 1070°C-1170°C for 6 h under ambient atmosphere.
Sintered ceramic specimens were polished and coated with silver electrodes on top and bottom surfaces.
Optimal sintered specimen with highest d33 was selected through experimental trials by adjusting sintering temperature.
Ceramic specimens were poled in silicone oil at 4 kV/mm for piezoelectric measurements.

method.reference: template grain growth (TGG) with solid-state reaction

reference_steps: High purity precursors were weighed according to stoichiometric ratio and mixed by ball-milling in anhydrous ethanol for 24 h.
Mixed powders were calcined at 850°C for 5 h to form main perovskite structure.
Slurry was prepared by mixing KNNS-(0.04-x)CZ-xBAZ matrix and NaNbO3 templates in ethanol/toluene co-solvent with PVB binder and MnO2 sintering aid.
Uniform slurry was tape casted to green tapes using doctor blade with thickness of 30-50 μm.
Green tapes were cut, stacked, and uniaxially pressed under 15 MPa at 70°C for 20 min.
Organic binder was removed at 600°C.
Samples were heated to 1190°C, then rapidly cooled to 1090°C and dwelled for 10 h.
Final textured ceramics were obtained after controlled cooling.

reference_steps: High-purity raw materials were weighed according to stoichiometry ratio of 0.957K0.48Na0.52Nb0.96Sb0.04O3-0.04Bi0.5Na0.5ZrO3-0.003CaZrO3.
Materials were ball milled with ethyl alcohol for 12 h at 300 rpm.
After drying, powders were divided into 4 batches and calcined at 800, 850, 900, and 950°C respectively.
Part of powders were pressed into compacts with diameter of 10 mm at 200 MPa using cold isostatic press.
Residual powders were subjected to another ball-milling for 24 h and pressed into pellets under same conditions.
All pellets were sintered using two-step sintering technique - rapidly raised to 1190°C at 10°C/min heating rate.
Temperature was rapidly cooled down to 1090°C and dwelled for 5 h before natural cooling.
For electrical measurements, samples were printed with silver paste and baked at 600°C for 30 min to form electrodes.
Samples were poled at 5 kV/cm for 30 min and aged for 20 h before testing.

reference_steps: Starting materials were mixed in stoichiometric ratios for Ba1-xSrxTi0.92Zr0.08O3 formula with x = 0, 0.04, 0.08, 0.12, 0.16, 0.2 mol.
Materials were subjected to ball milling in ethanol at 400 rpm for 12 h.
Mixture underwent drying and then fired at 1200°C for duration of 2 h.
After calcination, material was thoroughly blended with 5 wt% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA).
Mixture was compacted into discs measuring 15 mm across and 1 mm thickness by applying pressure of 10 MPa.
Molded ceramics were placed in muffle furnace, ramped to 650°C at rate of 5°C/min and held for 2 h to eliminate PVA.
Samples were heated to 1400°C at 5°C/min and sintered in air for 3 h.
For electrical characterization, ceramic surfaces were uniformly coated with silver paste on both sides.
Silver paste was cured by heating at 600°C for 30 min.
Ceramics were immersed in silicone oil bath at 40°C and subjected to polarization with DC field of 30 kV/cm for 20 min.

reference_steps: Raw materials were prepared for 0.725BiFe(1-x)ScxO3-0.275BaTiO3 ceramics with x = 0, 0.0025, 0.0050, 0.0075, 0.010, 0.015, 0.02.
Carbonates were dried in oven at 120°C for more than 2 h before use.
Raw materials were mixed by ball-milling machine in ethanol.
After drying, powder mixture was calcined twice at 800°C for 2 h.
Calcined powders were milled for 12 h and then pressed into disks with 12.7 mm diameter using polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) as binder.
Green compacts were first fired at 600°C to remove PVA binder.
Samples were sintered in ambient atmosphere at temperature range of 1000°C-1020°C for 2 h.

Gold electrodes were sputtered onto ceramic surfaces for electrical measurements.
Ceramics were polarized at 120°C in silicone oil bath under DC electric field ranging from 5 to 6 kV/mm for 15-20 min.

reference_steps: 0.74 Pb(Mg1/3Nb2/3)O3-0.26PbTiO3 (PMN-0.26 PT) single crystals were grown by modified Bridgman method.
As-grown single crystals were oriented by rotating XRD method.
[001]-oriented square slices were cut with size 4 × 4 × 0.8 mm³.
Layer of Ni was covered on (001) plane crystal slices to enhance binding force between single crystal and electrode.
Au electrode was sputtered on crystal slices for poling and electrical performance measurement.
All samples were annealed at 600°C for 10 h and then air-cooled to room temperature.
Samples were placed at room temperature for 2 days to completely release internal stress.
For electrical measurements, samples were poled using direct current poling (DCP) or alternating current poling (ACP) procedures.
During poling processes, single crystals were immersed in silicon oil to avoid arcing breakdown.
Electrical performance was measured 24 h after poling considering aging effect of materials.

Stored at room temperature for 2 days to release internal stress

reference_steps: AlN thin films were deposited by DC reactive magnetron sputtering from 100 × 300 mm² Al target (99.99% purity) using N2 and Ar as process gases.
Layers were deposited on 0.80-inch single side polished (100)-oriented Si substrates.
Substrates were cleaned in ultrasonic cleaning system: 5 minutes in Decon neutracon solvent, 5 minutes in WashBryte solvent, 5 minutes in deionized water.
Substrates were dried under N2 flow and loaded into deposition system under residual pressure around 10⁻⁷ mbar.
Al target was cleaned in pure Ar (flow of 30 sccm) at 300 W for 10 min to remove oxygen contamination.
Target was conditioned for 5 min in reactive atmosphere (Ar/N2 plasma) to reach stable reactive conditions.
AlN thin films were deposited using magnetron powers of 70-400 W and Ar & N2 flows of 20-40 sccm.
All experiments were conducted at room temperature with deposition time set at two hours.
Samples were characterized for thickness, morphology, crystallinity, and piezoelectric properties after deposition.
test_steps: Substrates cleaned in ultrasonic baths: Decon neutracon solvent (5 min), WashBryte solvent (5 min), and deionized water (5 min).
Substrates dried under N2 flow and loaded into deposition system under residual pressure ~10^-7 mbar.
Al target cleaned in pure Ar plasma (30 sccm, 300 W, 10 min) followed by reactive Ar/N2 plasma stabilization (5 min).
Deposition of AlN thin films using magnetron power (70-400 W), Ar (20-40 sccm), and N2 (20-40 sccm) gas flows.

reference_steps: Barium acetate, calcium acetate and tin acetate were added in 2-ethylhexanoic acid in stoichiometric ratio and dissolved by heating at 80°C until clear solution was obtained.
Desired stoichiometric quantity of C16H36O4Ti was mixed in the same solvent in separate beaker and then added to the previous solution.
Final solution was stirred and mixed for 1 h under continuous heating at 80°C.
Solution was dried to obtain BCST powder.
BCST powder was calcined at 1000°C for 4 h in muffle furnace.
Calcined powder was grinded in mortar pestle with 5 wt% polyvinyl alcohol solution until fine powder was obtained.
Pellets were prepared by compressing under 5 ton pressure.
Pellets were sintered at 1100°C and 1200°C for 5 h to get densified BCST ceramics samples.
test_steps: Barium acetate, calcium acetate monohydrate, and tin acetate were dissolved in 2-ethylhexanoic acid in stoichiometric ratio by heating at 80°C until a clear solution was obtained.
Stoichiometric quantity of titanium tetraisopropoxide was mixed in the same solvent and added to the previous solution.
Final solution was stirred and heated at 80°C for 1 hour.
Solution was dried to obtain BCST powder.
BCST powder was calcined at 1000°C for 4 hours in a muffle furnace.
Calcined powder was ground with 5 wt% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) solution to obtain fine powder.
Pellets were prepared by compressing the powder under 5 ton pressure.
Pellets were sintered at 1100°C and 1200°C for 5 hours to obtain densified ceramics.
Sintered pellets were polished and coated with silver paste on both faces for electrical contact.

reference_steps: Raw materials were accurately weighed according to stoichiometric ratio and subjected to milling in alcohol with zirconia balls for 12 hours.
Materials were dried and presintered at 750°C for 2 hours.
Calcined powder underwent additional ball-milling process lasting 24 hours.
Powders were mixed with 7 wt% polyvinyl alcohol and compressed into gray disks measuring 13 mm in diameter.
Prepared disks were sintered at temperatures ranging from 1180 to 1270°C in air for 3 hours.
Samples were polished and coated with silver as electrodes to facilitate electrical characterization.

reference_steps: Sodium acetate, strontium acetate, bismuth acetate, and barium acetate were weighed according to stoichiometric ratio and added to ethylene glycol methyl ether and acetic acid solvents.
12 mol% excess sodium acetate and 2 mol% excess bismuth acetate were used to compensate for possible evaporation during high-temperature annealing.
Tetrabutyl titanate mixed with acetylacetone was added to the mixture of acetate.
Precursor solution was obtained after stirring the mixture at 80°C for one hour.
Solution concentration of 0.4 mol/L was achieved by adjusting the solvent content.
Solution was deposited on pretreated Pt/TiO2/SiO2/Si substrates by spin coating at 1500 r/min for 10 s and then 3000 r/min for 40 s.
Deposited film was placed in rapid thermal treatment furnace for pyrolysis at 150°C for 3 min and then at 410°C for 10 min.
Annealing process was conducted at 725°C for 3 min for crystallization.
Deposition and heating procedures were repeated 6 times to prepare thin films with designed thickness.
Au electrodes with diameter of 0.3 mm were prepared by DC sputtering.
test_steps: Sodium acetate, strontium acetate, bismuth acetate, and barium acetate were weighed in stoichiometric ratio with 12 mol% excess sodium acetate and 2 mol% excess bismuth acetate to compensate for evaporation during annealing.
The mixture was stirred at 80°C for one hour to obtain the precursor solution of BNT-ST-100xBT.
The solution concentration was adjusted to 0.4 mol/L by adjusting the solvent content.
The precursor solution was deposited on pretreated Pt/TiO2/SiO2/Si substrates via spin coating at 1500 r/min for 10 s followed by 3000 r/min for 40 s.
The deposited film underwent heat treatment in a rapid thermal processing (RTP) furnace: pyrolysis at 150°C for 3 min, pyrolysis at 410°C for 10 min, and annealing at 725°C for 3 min.
The deposition and heating procedures were repeated six times to achieve the designed film thickness.
Au electrodes with a diameter of 0.3 mm were deposited onto the film surface using DC sputtering.

reference_steps: Raw materials were precisely weighed on the basis of stoichiometric ratio and mixed in deionized water.
Materials were grounded for 6 h by ball-milling with ratio of materials to balls to water as 1:2:1.
Powder was pressed into blocks and calcined at 850°C for 2 hours.
Calcined powder was ball-milled for 12 hours again to obtain uniform PMS-PZT powder.
Dried powder combined with PVA binder was pressed into pellets of diameter 20 mm and thickness 1.4 mm at pressure of 7 MPa.
Green bodies were heated at 550°C for 3 h to remove the PVA.
Green bodies were sintered at 1250°C for 2 h in sealed alumina crucible with same composition powder on surface to minimize PbO evaporation.
Sintered ceramics were ground into thickness of 1 mm.
Silver electrodes were fired on top and bottom surfaces at 720°C for 20 min.
Ceramics were poled in silicon oil at 130°C for 40 minutes under DC electric field of 35 kV/mm.
Polarized ceramics were aged for at least 24 hours at room temperature before testing.

Polarized ceramics aged for ≥24 hours at room temperature before testing

reference_steps: Raw powders were weighed according to stoichiometric formulae and ball milled for 24 h in polypropylene containers with ethanol and ZrO2 balls using planetary milling machine.
After drying the mixture, first calcination process was carried out at 850°C for 2 h to prevent volatilization of Bi3+.
Second calcination cycle was conducted at 900°C for 4 h.
Calcined powder was re-milled for 24 h and thermally treated in additional two-stage calcination process at 950°C for 4 h, followed by calcination at 1000°C for 2 h.
Obtained powder was milled again for 4 h to homogeneously reduce particle size.
Powder was mixed with 5 wt% polyvinyl alcohol binder in mortar and uniaxial cold-pressed into pellets with diameter of 12 mm.
Pellets were covered with powder of same composition and sintered at 1100°C for 2 h in sealed alumina crucibles.
Calcination and sintering processes were performed at heating rate of 5°C/min.
Drying procedures were carried out at 120°C on hot plate for 12 h.

Drying at 120°C for 12 h

reference_steps: Weighed chemicals were wet-milled in polyethylene bottles with ZrO2 balls for 12 h in ethanol.
Materials were calcined at 750°C for 3 hours.
Calcined powders were milled, dried, ground, and granulated with polyvinyl alcohol binder.
Granulated powders were pressed into discs with diameters of 12.5 mm and thicknesses of 1.0 mm at pressure of 150 MPa.
Pellets were heated to 650°C for 60 min to burn out the binder.
Samples were sintered at 1080°C for 3 h.
Sintered samples were polished to thickness of approximately 0.5 mm.
Silver paste was screen-printed onto two parallel polished surfaces, followed by firing at 570°C for 30 min.

reference_steps: Precursors were dried for minimum of 12 hours in 120°C drying oven prior to planetary ball milling.
Ball milling was conducted in 100% ethanol with 250 mL ZrO2 milling jar and 5 mm ZrO2 media for 3 h at 125 rpm.
Resulting slurry was dried using rotary evaporator, ground with agate mortar and pestle, and sieved with 250 μm mesh stainless steel sieve.
Three individual calcination pellets with nominal weight of 3.0 g and diameter of 25 mm were uniaxially pressed under 5 MPa.
Calcination pellets were calcined in partially closed alumina crucible at 801.5°C for 4 hours with heating rate of 3°C/min and cooling rate of approximately 4°C/min.
Following calcination, pellets were milled in 100% ethanol with 250 mL ZrO2 milling jar and 5 mm ZrO2 media for 30 minutes at 125 rpm.
Resulting slurry was dried using rotary evaporator, ground with agate mortar and pestle, and sieved with 150 μm mesh stainless steel sieve.
Approximately 24 sintering pellets with nominal weight of 0.30 g and diameter of 10 mm were uniaxially pressed under 30 MPa.
Pellets were isostatically pressed under 200 MPa with dwell time of one minute.
Pellets were sintered in batches of 3 in partially closed alumina crucible at 1103.5°C for 2 hours with heating rate of 5°C/min and cooling rate of approximately 4°C/min.

Carbon coating (20 nm thickness) for SEM/EDX analysis

reference_steps: Powders were precisely weighed according to stoichiometric ratios and transferred to nylon tube for 12 h of ball milling in alcohol dispersing medium.
Mixed slurry was dried and calcined at 850°C for 4 h.
Calcined powder was subsequently milled again for 12 h.
0.3 g of ceramic powder was pressed into disc with diameter of 8 mm and thickness of 1.3 mm under pressure of 250 MPa.
Surface of green bodies was covered with ceramic powder of same composition and sintered in air at 1100°C for 4 h to obtain dense ceramic sheets.
Samples were polished to required thickness and platinum electrodes were applied and cured on both sides.
Samples were polarized in silicone oil bath at 180°C under electric field of 160-200 kV/cm for 30 min.

reference_steps: Nonwoven ES fiber mats of P(VDF-TrFE) 80/20 were prepared from 12 wt% methyl ether ketone solution using electrospinning equipped with grounded rolling collector.

First thermal annealing (1A) process was performed by holding ES fiber mat isothermally at 140°C for various times (10, 60, 180, 360, 720, 1440, and 2880 min) to produce ECCs via chain-sliding motions in paraelectric phase.
Second annealing (2A) was carried out for ES1A-2880 min below TC with fixed isothermal time of 1 day at temperatures of 110, 115, 125, and 130°C to further increase ferroelectric domain size.
Corona-charging was employed to achieve permanent remanent polarization for piezoelectricity.
For corona-poling in water, methanol was used to wet fiber mats first and then replaced with water.
AC corona poling at 500 kHz was performed in water to avoid formation of ionic EDLs and potential electrolytic degradation.
After corona-poling in water, samples were dried in vacuum before characterization.

method.reference: mixed oxide method with composite fabrication

reference_steps: BZT powder was prepared by calcining barium carbonate, zirconium dioxide and titanium dioxide at 1200°C for 2 h using mixed oxide method.
BZT powder was pressed into disc shape of ~15 mm diameter and thickness of ~1.5 mm at applied pressure of ~85 MPa.
BZT discs were sintered at 1450°C for 2 h.
BZT discs (dimension ~12 mm and thickness ~1.5 mm) were poled using electric field of 1.5 kV/mm at 50°C for 30 min in silicone oil chamber.
Poled BZT ceramic was cut using diamond saw in parallel direction along polarization axis using cut and fill method.
Mixtures of Portland cement powder, water (w/c ratio 0.35), epoxy resin and hardener (volume ratio 7.5) were prepared as matrix phase.
Mixture was filled into cut areas of BZT ceramic to create 1-3 connectivity composites with 40, 50, and 60 vol% BZT and 0, 3, 5, and 7 vol% epoxy resin.
Samples were cured in controlled chamber at 60°C for 5 days at 98% RH.
Sc2O3 and Nb2O5 powders were wet-mixed via ball milling for 12 h, followed by calcination at 1050°C for 6 h to obtain precursor ScNbO4.
Precursors were mixed with PbO, ZrO2, TiO2, MnO2, and Sb2O3 before being calcined at 850°C for 2 h to achieve desired composition of PZT-PMS-PSN.
Resultant powder was crushed for 8 h and then dried.
Fine powder was mixed with PVA binder at mass concentration of 7% and pressed to form Φ10mm pellets at pressure of 150 MPa.
After binder was cremated at 800°C for 2 h, PZT-PMS-PSN samples were sintered at 1180°C for 2 h.
Sintered pellets were polished to reach about 0.5 mm thickness.
Both sides of sample were coated with silver paste and fired at 800°C for 10 min for electrical property measurements.
Samples were polarized for 30 min at 180°C in silicone oil bath at DC field strength of 5 kV/mm for piezoelectric measurements.

reference_steps: In2Se3@SnSe S-scheme heterojunction piezo-photocatalysts were prepared using two-step hydrothermal method.
SnSe displays typical nanoplate morphology while In2Se3 exhibits nanosheet structure.
Chemical reaction involving Se in SnSe produces In2Se3 during heterojunction formation.
All In2Se3@SnSe heterojunctions exhibit flower-like spherical structure.
Varying molar content of SnSe was used to create different compositions (In2Se3@SnSe-1, In2Se3@SnSe-2, In2Se3@SnSe-3, In2Se3@SnSe-4).
Heterojunction formation results in interfacial interaction and electron transfer from SnSe to In2Se3.

reference_steps: Raw materials were accurately weighed according to composition (1-x)(Ba0.95Ca0.05)(Ti0.89Sn0.11)O3-xBiFeO3 and milled with ethanol for 16 h.
After drying at 100°C, powders were calcined at 1150°C for 3 h.
Calcined powders were re-milled with ethanol for 16 h.
Powders were pressed into disks of 9 mm diameter using 3% PVA solution as binder.
Green bodies were fired at 600°C for 2 h and then sintered at 1400°C for 3 h.
Sintered ceramics were polished and coated with silver paste on top and bottom surfaces.
Silver-coated ceramics were fired at 800°C for 30 min to obtain electrodes.
Coated ceramics were poled at 50 kV/cm DC field for 30 min at room temperature in silicone oil bath.

reference_steps: Stoichiometric ratios of high-purity precursors BaCO3, CaCO3, ZrO2, SnO2, and TiO2 were mixed.
Combinations were ground for 2 hours in mortar and pestle.
Materials were ball milled for 4 hours in ethanol solution with zirconia balls in low-energy ball mill.
Resulting solutions were dried and obtained lumps were pulverized.
Powders were calcined for 4 hours at 1200°C in air ambient.
Resulting granulated powders were reground.
1 wt% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) was added as organic binder.
Materials were molded into disk-shaped pellets (1 mm thick and 10 mm diameter).
Pellets were heated for 1 hour at 650°C at rate of 1°C per minute to burn off PVA binder.
Binder-free pellets underwent sintering for 4 hours at 1400°C in air.
Sintered pellets were electroded on opposite faces with conducting silver paste for electrical measurements.

reference_steps: Mixed 1 g colemanite, 80 mg Fe2O3, 500 mg BaCO3, and 500 mg TiO2.
Subjected mixture to ball milling for 15 h at rotational speed of 300 rpm.
Added 2 mL of 13.8 M ammonia solution to mixture and ball-milled for additional 3 min at same speed.
Transferred resulting mixture onto silicon carbide plate (3 cm × 2 cm).
Evaporated ammonia solution by heating plate on hot plate set to 150°C.
Placed SiC plate with residual mixture into tubular furnace.
Gradually increased furnace temperature to 1300°C and maintained for 3 h under continuous NH3 gas flow.
Stopped NH3 gas flow at 975°C upon completion of reaction.
Allowed furnace to cool to room temperature.
Carefully removed composite material from SiC plate for characterization.

reference_steps: Raw materials CeO2, Bi2O3, TiO2, and Nb2O5 were weighed according to BTN-100xCe nominal composition.
Materials were ball mixed for 24 hours with anhydrous ethanol and zirconia balls medium.
Mixed slurries were separated from balls and dried.
Dried materials were calcined at 800°C for 3 hours.
Calcined materials were ball milled for 24 hours again and dried.
Dried powders were granulated with 5 wt% polyvinyl alcohol solution as adhesive.
Granulated powders were pressed into green pellets of 13 mm diameter and 1.0 mm thick under 120±10 MPa pressure.
Green pellets were fired at 650°C for 3 hours to burn off PVA.
Pellets were sintered at 1065-1105°C for 3 hours in air with 5°C/min heating rate.
Sintered samples were furnace-cooled to ambient temperature.

reference_steps: Raw materials Ba(CH3COO)2, Ca(NO3)2·4H2O, Zr(NO3)4·5H2O, Ti(OC4H9)4 and La(NO3)3·nH2O were added to an Erlenmeyer flask to gain a polymer solution.
Solution was placed in the oven at 120°C for 10 h to obtain gels.
Gels were calcined at 900°C for 2 h to form precursor powders.
Powders were pressed into disks with a diameter of 20 mm.
Disks were embedded in alumina.
Disks were sintered at 1300°C for 4 h in air with a heating rate of 5°C/min.
Ceramic samples were obtained.

reference_steps: Raw materials BaCO3, CaCO3, ZrO2 and TiO2 were weighed according to the stoichiometric ratio.
Raw materials were mixed with ethanol and ball-milled for 24 h.
Ethanol-ceramic slurry was dried in an oven and ground into a powder.
Powder was calcined at 1250°C for 3 h with a heating ramping rate of 5°C/min.
Calcinated powders were ground and sieved using a mesh with a size of 63 μm.
For dense ceramics: PVA was mixed with BCZT powders as binding agent.
Mixture was uni-axially cold-compacted at a pressure of 80 MPa to form green body.
Green body was heated to 500°C for 2 h using a ramp rate of 1°C/min to burn out organic agents.
Final sintering at 1400°C for 10 h with a ramp rate of 5°C/min.
Sintered ceramics were formed into dimension with thickness of 1 mm and diameter of 10 mm.

Calcinated powders ground and sieved using 63 µm mesh
Dense BCZT: mixed with PVA binder, uni-axially cold-compacted at 80 MPa to form green body
Dense BCZT sintering: heated to 500°C for 2 h (1°C/min ramp) to burn out organics, followed by high-temperature sintering at 1400°C for 10 h (5°C/min ramp)
Porous BCZT: ball-milled with deionized water, PVA binder, and ammonium polyacrylate dispersion agent to form 20 vol% slurry
Porous BCZT slurry poured into cylindrical mold with PDMS sides and metal bottom, unidirectionally frozen at -80°C
Freeze-drying to remove ice and form porous green body
Porous BCZT sintered under identical conditions as dense BCZT
Sintered ceramics machined into 1 mm thickness × 10 mm diameter dimensions
